Collapsing, widespread; Instability rapidly rising; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We noted a very weak snowpack structure on nearly all aspects in Hellroaring Canyon in the Centennials. Huge layers of facets underly a very thin snowpack. Although we did not get positive ECT results at 7,800’, we believe there just hasn’t been enough slab deposited on top of this weak structure to activate it. These persistent weak layers are very large and widespread. New and/or rapid snow loading should not be taken lightly.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Looks like the bowl above snow pit avalanched during east wind event on 12/31.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Widespread surface hoar observed on the way up. On W and NE aspects. 3-4 mm in size. Most open areas were covered with surface hoar from the time we left the cars at 9820 ft. up to 106oo ft. SH was on a variable surface layer of snow ranging from P hard wind crust ( 3- 5 cm) to soft and powdery snow in sheltered areas and MF crust on solar aspects.
Stability tests didn't break. The snowpack just crumbled beneath the shovel. Faceted snowpack for sure, but not too bad for Uintas.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank; Recent activity on similar slopes; We skied slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown profile of Sa in Hang 'em High. 11th skier on slope triggered size 2 in small sheltered lee slope, failing on SH 3-5mm. Avalanche stopped in track. Slope is a protected lee with wind loaded roll up against a tree fence, low angle short slope at high BTL/low TL.

Depth hoar crystals found at the bottom of the snowpack. Some rounds and rounding edges within the crystals were observed. The resistance is 1F-. These crystals are slowly gaining strength.

I found the Dec. 8th buried surface hoar at 57 cm. but it was no longer intact, and nearly indistinguishable from the surrounding layers (thus this layer has the same hardness as the adjacent layers).

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: moderate easterly wind gusts. otherwise light and calm winds. CT's were a little tricky to document. Noticed some minor failures CTE 2 @ 73cm and CTE 6 @ 53, little to now sheer. Call it Q3, Im not sure.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Collapsing, localized
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit was dug in within the boundary of a ski area, however location is a closed area with no skier traffic and no control work done at this point in the season, so should be fairly representative of similar slopes in the backcountry. No propagation during standard ECT test, but did get propagation at 93cm at 11 upon hitting other side of column after test completion. Overall looks better than the more northerly slopes in area, no depth hoar formation noticed, however still some significant faceted layers, in particular from 21cm to ground that have very limited cohesion.
Test: Look for PWLs on unmodified N aspects

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Very windy. Widespread temperature crust on almost all aspects, variable thickness, skiable zipper curst. Dissipated at higher elevations. Hard, thick and unreactive wind slabs along ridge lines and mid-slope loading zones. Observed minor cracking along north ridge. Old avalanche debris visible in main east bowl avy path. A cold day. A lot of blowing snow. East bowl total and Avg HS:170 cm / 12.13 ice layer @ 70cm from surface.

Pit located just north of the powerlines at the head of the Left hand of Arthurs Fork. The main point of this pit was to look for facets at the ground to get a sense of what might exist at 9k in this area. At this elevation, I am not concerned about this layer. At 9k, I think the faceted layer is much thicker and a potential problem.

Crown Profile for the avalanche from December 26th, 2018 on the ESE side of the Nose of Four Pines (LOBB). Stability tests were performed on an aspect 10 degrees less than the avalanche occured on 15 feet from the crown where the weak layer did not collapse. On this aspect the bed surface crust was not present.

Pit adjacent to recent skier-triggered slide. Slight differences in aspect (just North of East versus just South of East) had a significantly different structure. The slide had a 50' wide start zone with ESE aspect. On E facing terrain just skier's left, I didn't see the MF crust that formed the bed surface for the slide.

User.name: Andy Anderson

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This crown profile was made during the investigation of the December 22 Horse Creek Fatality in the Wyoming Range. The primary failure was 53 cm above the ground on faceted snow that likely began as buried near surface facets. In a small area above the burial location, the avalanche scoured down to the 1 finger faceted layer below and also failed on the fist hard facets at the base of the snowpack.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Observed Blowing Snow on Ridgetops

TOTAL HS: 192 cm / 75 in. A lot of snow moving around, giant plumes of spindrift off ridge lines, most sublimating to the east. Ridgelines scoured and plastered in bullet proof ice and rime. New snow: 2" BTL / 3" NTL / 4" ATL . Variable conditions, sastrugi features, packed powder, powder on top of a formerly breakable crust, icy surfaces...it's all out there. Snow surfaces generally smooth. Despite a lot of blowing snow, no avalanches were observed. High winds blew most snow off mountain while some collected in gullies and low angle terrain.

User.name: Nick Meyers

Shallow snow in the Beaver Mt. Area is faceted throughout and very soft in many areas with less 2 feet of total snow. This is on a west facing, forested slope. Similar snow depth and structure noted across the area

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Also did PST x2 in nearby location, same aspect & elevation. PST 94/100 END down 15cm on SH; PST 90/100 END down 30 cm on SH. Then added simulation of new load (~20 cm pencil hard snow) and got very different results: PST 10/100 END down 30cm on SH; PST 10/100 SF down 15 cm on SH. These results suggest propagation propensity of SH layers in upper snowpack may increase with added load.
